<math>\sigma = \sqrt{Var[X]},\quad\text{with}\quad Var[X]=E[X^2] - (E[X])^2.</math>

question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
At first we calculate the Variance \(Var[X]\).

\[\begin{aligned} Var[X]&= E[X^2]-(E[X])^2\\ &= \int_1^ex^2\cdot\frac1xdx - (e-1)^2\\ &= \int_1^exdx - (e-1)^2\\ &= \left.\frac{x^2}{2}\right|_1^e - (e-1)^2\\ &= \frac{e^2}2 - \frac12 - e^2 +2e -1 \\ &= -\frac{e^2}2+2e-\frac32 \\ &= -\frac12(e-3)(e-1)\\ &= \frac12(3-e)(e-1) \quad (\approx 0.242)\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \sigma=\sqrt{\frac12(3-e)(e-1)}\approx0.492\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Streptococcus viridans bacteria divide along a preferred axis and therefore form chains when they divide. You study a population of S. viridans in a blood culture. Let X be the length (in µm) of a randomly chosen chain. Its distribution is described by the probability density function

\[\begin{aligned} p(x) = \frac1{x}, \quad 1 \leq x \leq e\end{aligned}\]

Find the standard deviation of X.
